campaign.story:
That house on the outskirts of town, sitting empty behind a crumbling wall. The one people whisper about. The one that has gone unlived in for years. Sometimes a few hearty souls creep in, it is said, to see what treasures or secrets they can find. Most find nothing—just an empty old house. Some return shaken. A few don’t return at all.
You’ve seen this house before. If not in this city, then in some other. You’ve heard the rumors—and if you haven’t, well, someday they’ll find you.
What happens to a house when it sits alone for so many long years? What jealousies and hatreds does it quietly nurture? What whispers echo through its empty hallways? What waits, crouched within its dark rooms, hungering for the return of life?
For you.
The Darkest House is a tabletop roleplaying game (RPG) product built from the ground up for online play, with unique features that take advantage of the online environment for an awesome experience. It's compatible with the game you're playing now. In fact, it's made for it! That’s because The Darkest House derives its horror from the bonds, backstories, ideals, loves, and fears your existing characters bring into it. Experiencing it will add depth to your campaign, your party, and your characters—those who come out alive!
Cross the threshold. Explore The Darkest House. The experience will change and challenge your PCs, their party, and your gaming group. And you won't have to wait long: You'll  have everything you need to bring The Darkest House to your campaign in May (with extras and exclusives to follow).
Scroll down to try a preview of The Darkest House!
The Darkest House is a digital product designed specifically to the needs of running and playing games online—and built to take maximum advantage of that mode of play. Think of it like an RPG book reimagined to make the most of the online environment. Every image and map is conveniently shareable and downloadable. Each encounter is formatted to your screen, giving you everything you need in a single view. Text for sharing with the players is easily copied with a single click. A rich network of hyperlinks makes navigation simple and intuitive. The Darkest House is as easy on the GM as the house itself is challenging to the PCs.
Use The Darkest House in conjunction with your preferred online TTRPG platform: run your game on Zoom or Discord, or use a virtual tabletop (VTT) like Roll20 or Astral. Only the GM needs a copy of The Darkest House—like a conventional RPG product, it gives the GM the information, resources, and tools to run the game, plus loads of handouts, images, and other sharable items to distribute, as appropriate, to the players.
The Darkest House consists of:
The downloadable product, containing the many dozens of rooms of the house itself. This is what the GM will primarily use during play. There’s enough content for many visits to the house, and dozens of hours of play—and through stretch goals the house continues to grow!
 The Darkest House: Secrets of the House in PDF, a GM's guide detailing the House's background, conversion rules, and the House Rules set you'll use as your PCs explore, and try to escape from, the Darkest House.
 The Darkest House Player's Guide in PDF, which gives players the character conversion rules and everything they need to explore (and try to escape from) the Darkest House.
To use The Darkest House, the GM will need a desktop or laptop computer running macOS or Windows and a broadband internet connection. Scroll down to try a preview of The Darkest House.
How It Works
Although The Darkest House is a completely new type of product, you'll use it in basically the same way you use a typical RPG book or PDF—it's just easier and has a lot more features for online play. You'll still use a VTT or videoconference platform (such as Roll20 or Zoom) to run your game. Your players won't access The Darkest House app itself—like a physical adventure book, it's just for the GM. (You will share The Darkest House Player's Guide PDF, and loads of handouts, maps, and images with them, though.)
Here's an example: Charles normally runs his games using Zoom for audio and video, and Slack for text messaging, sharing JPGs of handouts, and rolling dice. In addition, he has his game books and notes open on his desk beside him, or PDFs and other files open on his computer. When running The Darkest House, he'll use Zoom and Slack the same way, and keep The Darkest House app open on his computer in place of all those books or PDFs. He can share maps, images, and text with just a click or two, pasting them into his Slack channel as the PCs encounter new rooms, creatures, and clues.
LaTia runs her games on Roll20. The Darkest House works the same way in that environment, with one additional advantage: LaTia can set up her encounters in advance, downloading the maps and resources before the game starts and setting them up within Roll20.
Try It!
Want to see how it works? Check out the preview of The Darkest House now for a look at a few of the rooms and features. Download it for either macOS or Windows (below). Open it, have a look at the intro page, and explore as you see fit—or take this little tour:
Click Explore The Darkest House Now on the right side of the intro page and you'll find yourself in the Boundless Room, just one example of the House's many, many rooms.
See the words Pried Up Floorboards on the map? Click them, and the description will open to the right.
Some items aren't tagged on the map. Click The Giggling Ghost at the bottom right of the screen.
Under the first set of boxed text, and click the Copy Text button. Return to this Kickstarter, go into the comments, and paste. That's how easy it is to copy and paste info for the players. Features like these make the most of the online environment—making it an advantage instead of an impediment!
You can also share images and maps just as easily. Go to The Family Portrait and click Download under the handout to download the image, or "Copy Link" to paste the link into a chat or browser window to share it that way. You can do the same with the room map and main illustration.
The portrait holds the secret to escaping this particular room. Click the link to the Interior Courtyard to continue your exploration of the House.
Continue to explore to discover the many ways The Darkest House stands apart from conventional RPG products. This preview of the app is not final and only demonstrates a small portion of The Darkest House. The final product may differ slightly.
That old house that everyone whispers about. That apartment at the end of the hall where no tenant ever stays for long. That strange unit in the station quarters sector, where everything seems a bit off. These are among the many entrances to the Darkest House.
Like an invasive vine or a creeping shadow, the Darkest House insinuates itself into any universe. It is a malignant and primal force, unconcerned with the specifics of the worlds it seeps into. The Darkest House exists in our world—in your world—in any world. Wherever there is hunger, the Darkest House can gain a foothold. It is perfectly happy to take root in your campaign.
Or campaigns. The house draws from the many worlds it touches. It need not pull all its victims from the same setting. Imagine an experience that gathers your favorite characters from different campaigns to work together to survive its horrors. As a product specially designed for online play, scattered gaming groups can come back together for a unique reunion experience.
The Darkest House’s effect on character development and backstory makes it really shine when introduced to existing characters and campaigns. It will influence the quality of play for long after the characters have escaped it. 
Inject the Darkest House into your ongoing campaign as a horror interlude or as a recurring encounter. It works as a standalone one-shot, but there’s far more to the house than that. With many dozens of rooms (and growing, through stretch goals) adding up to 30-50 hours of game play, PCs who escape the house might stumble upon it later, seek it out to further plumb its mysteries, or find themselves drawn into it again to free themselves and their world of its darkness.
The house has many aspects, and there will always be more to discover.
The House System
The Darkest House isn't just compatible with the game you’re already playing—it was made for it! Within The Darkest House, you’ll use the House System. You’ll quickly and easily convert your existing characters (it takes about five minutes) and use those stats while in The Darkest House. Once the PCs emerge, your players will return to their regular setting using their regular character sheets. The House System is a sort of RPG Rosetta Stone, allowing easy translation into and out of any game system—and even letting you bring characters from different games together.
The House System is tailored for tension and terror. With each die roll, the players roll the House Die, which might indicate that the house itself takes an action. Players can call upon the essence of the house while they're within it to turn a failure into a success, but every time they do so they accumulate personal Doom. Escaping the house with the weight of such Doom on their shoulders, characters may find themselves scarred, cursed, or haunted in all manner of disturbing ways, carrying remnants of their experience back into their home campaigns long after they've left.
It's possible to launch a campaign centered around the Darkest House. But that's not what the house wants. It is strongest when it reaches into an ongoing campaign to test and challenge existing characters. That’s because events in the Darkest House will change characters and alter the campaign setting. The house gets its metaphorical claws into those that cross its threshold, and the house itself changes based on who those characters are, who they have loved, who they have hated, and where they have been. Characters who explore the house and make it back out are never quite the same.
Want even deeper mysteries? More secrets? More dangers? The Devoured Halls is a separate portion of the Darkest House, with its own rooms, its own secret entrance and exit, and its own mysteries to uncover. Within this section of the house, characters might discover that perhaps the house isn't fully in control of itself… the house itself might be broken. While The Darkest House is a complete package, The Devoured Halls adds its own flavor and offers its own experience in keeping with the rest of the house. It fits in seamlessly and offers additional depth and an entirely new mini story for characters to investigate. 
The Devoured Halls backer level includes the complete Darkest House plus the additional content in the Devoured Halls—a Kickstarter exclusive available only through this campaign. Backing at this level has even more exclusive benefits—you also get:
Monte Cook's secret tour of the Darkest House: In the style of a director's commentary track, Monte takes you on a video tour of the House covering his favorite rooms. He delves into their genesis and inspiration, gives you insights into the lore behind them, and talks about how he's used them in his own games.
The Darkest House digital art book: The Darkest House contains dozens and dozens of illustrations, all as mysterious as they are beautiful. The Art of The Darkest House presents all of them—including illustrations from the Devoured Halls—in beautiful detail. Annotations by Monte and Art Director Bear Weiter accompany many of the illustrations, and several also include details or alternate versions calling out their secrets and hidden features.
Monte Cook has designed many RPGs over his 30+ year career, including Dungeons & Dragons 3rd Edition, the Cypher System, Numenera, and Invisible Sun. He wanted to share why he he was inspired to create The Darkest House, and what design decisions he made. Check out his insights below.
I'm Monte Cook, and I created and designed the Darkest House. I've been using the essence of it in various campaigns for years, and I thought I'd take a moment to describe why I designed it the way I have, and hopefully why you'll find it intriguing and interesting as well.
Why Focus on Online Gaming?
At Monte Cook Games, we're spread out all across the continent. We've been regularly playing RPGs on Zoom or Roll20 since well before the pandemic, as of course many gamers have. In the 21st Century, gaming online has become a standard feature of tabletop games, and the last year or so has accelerated that aspect of running and playing games to an incredible degree. Gaming online has its own challenges, but it has its own strengths as well. As a designer, I've been pondering how to not just focus on the needs of online play, but to in fact embrace online play, bringing the aspects of gaming that it does particularly well to the fore. The ability to share art, to share text, and to send individual players direct messages are just some of the things that The Darkest House not just enables but shines a spotlight upon. Meanwhile, the difficulties of online gaming, such as managing lots of information, maintaining a mood, and dealing with cumbersome mechanics are all facets of the experience that the Darkest House eases.
Why Focus on Cross-System Play?
One of the things that's been true of a lot of us over the last year is a desire to reconnect with old pals or faraway friends. If your primary means of socializing is a video conference, people a thousand miles away are no farther away than those up the street. Still, talking to your friends through a computer screen can sometimes be hard. With all the additional barriers that online gaming can create, why should game systems add another?
The Darkest House offers an easy way to quickly convert the essence of any character from any system into a simple but interesting character who operates within the house's own, specific rules, tailored to the experiences within. My dream is that people will use The Darkest House as an excuse to rekindle that lapsed campaign with their old gaming group separated by time and distance, regardless of what system was being used. Or, perhaps even more exciting, the GM who's got a selection of friends who never regularly game together and use different systems can take their existing characters, temporarily convert them to the House System, and all go on an exciting and challenging (or horrifying) adventure together.
I believe that RPGs bring people together, and I hope that The Darkest House brings people together who might not otherwise get to easily enjoy each other's company. (And what better way to rekindle old bonds than in absolute terror?) 
Why a Haunted House?
Inspired by games like Kitty Horrowshow's Anatomy, books like Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves, and films like Stanley Kubrick's The Shining, I realized that the horror genre and haunted houses in particular offer unique opportunities to shine a light on characters, and RPGs are all about characters. I wanted to create an adventure that would deepen the characters even as it put them through their paces.
When PCs enter the Darkest House, they'll find far more than just a haunted house. It is a crucible of sorts, where their mettle and their minds will be tested. Those who fall short will suffer heavy consequences. Those who can hold their own, however, emerge more deeply developed with a greater insight into their world, their companions, and most of all themselves. The Darkest House forces players to think about their characters' deepest fears, dreams, their families, and their faith in their friends. Encounters are designed to focus less on damage dealt or resources used and more on the personalities, past experiences, and fundamental truths of a character. And if a character is lacking any of those, the Darkest House will enable the GM and players to work together to create them, or flesh them out, as needed.
If you've read this far, you've very likely picked up on the fact that within the Darkest House, it's the house itself that is the enemy. I have long had a fascination with fictional places with a mind or an essence all their own. And when that essence evolves over a long period of loneliness, neglect, and exposure to darkness and suffering, it makes for a truly unique "villain" far different than any ghost, specter, or demon could ever hope to be. And if that location, that house, grows and seeps in both space and time, devouring the very locations and loved ones important to those that cross its doorstep, well... I don't want to get into spoiler territory. Let's just say, if nothing else, The Darkest House certainly offers some unique experiences that will create stories your players will be talking about for years to come.
If you choose any physical add-on items, please check our Kickstarter Redemption page for information on reward redemption and shipping costs.

The Campaign Is Over, and the House Is Appeased … for Now
updates.update_content:
The house invited you in … and you entered.
The house hungered … and you fed it.
The house was alone … and you joined it.

updates.update_userinfo: Graphics Unlocked! But the House Has Other Concerns...
updates.update_content:
You have once again unlocked a stretch goal, and your games will now be graced by a suite of online graphics including backgrounds, wallpapers, and streaming frames.
But the house does not care about that. The house is hungry. It wants to grow. It wants you to feed it!
At $205,000, the house will grow once more. As it has before, it will form new rooms—or take them from the worlds it invades. It will gain roughly three new rooms, and The Devoured Halls will expand by at least one room as well.

updates.update_userinfo: The House Has Grown Again! (Plus New Art!)
updates.update_content:
Once again the house has grown. Your support has brought new rooms into being. This is perhaps fortunate for you, as your reward grows and you gain even more gameplay in the house. But it’s less fortunate for anyone who cherished those rooms in their own worlds. Especially if they were in them at the time.
What is next?

updates.update_userinfo: The House Has Grown Again, but It Is Never Enough…
updates.update_content:
The House that Hungers: that’s another name by which the Darkest House is known. Its appetite for your dreams and nightmares can never be stated. It has many rooms, but they are never enough for it.
Thanks to your support, the house has once again grown. It is bigger, home to more horror, and so is your reward for backing this campaign. The Devoured Halls have grown as well.

updates.update_userinfo: Seminar Unlocked! Now the House Hungers Again!
updates.update_content:
The house is full of unexpected truths. Few of them are as astonishing as your success in driving us to another stretch goal so quickly after we hit the last one!
The seminar with Monte is unlocked. Monte will share his secrets and best practices for making the most of your experience running The Darkest House. You'll get lots of tips and tricks for a game your players—for better or worse!—will never forget.

The house has called to you. It is hungry; it wants to grow.
And you heard its call. You answered. You brought it new backers and new worlds. And the house has grown accordingly. Over the past several days we have hit not one but two stretch goals, and the house’s appetite has, for the moment at least, quieted.
If it sleeps, however briefly, perhaps it is wise that we should let it rest. So we’ll ignore its hunger for a while at least. At $150,000, we will add a video seminar to your rewards, led by Monte himself. GMing The Darkest House is, in many ways, much like running any horror game online. But there are many tricks and best practices for getting the absolute most out of it—for really immersing your players in the experience, and maximizing the impact on their characters and your campaign. With Monte’s insights, you’ll give your players an experience they’ll never forget!

updates.update_userinfo: GM Tools Added! What Does the House Do Next?

Everything about The Darkest House is designed to optimize the GM’s experience when running games online. With this latest stretch goal reached, you've unlocked  a suite of GM tools that will make The Darkest House even easier to run.

5 years ago, players took a chance visit to the small town of Tall Oaks… and Mixtape Massacre was born.

Mixtape Massacre is a tabletop board game where 2 to 6 players terrorize the town and compete in an over the top fictional killing spree to be remembered. Dripping with nostalgic 1980’s pop-culture and classic horror tropes - Mixtape Massacre will have you laughing while you’re slashing! Dispatch victims, collect kills and brawl with fellow slashers to prove once and for all who is the baddest of the brood!

Even better, the Director’s Cut edition boasts updated rules and components, improved mechanics and even more killer additions to create the ultimate version of the game.

Welcome to the next chapter of Tall Oaks — Mixtape Massacre: Director's Cut
 And even more can be added with Stretch Goals...

campaign.story:
Back in late 2019, I was working a job I really didn't enjoy and feeling very creatively frustrated so I pondered an idea for a new puzzle book. (I had just released my first book in July of that year.) Inspired by choose your own adventure novels of the past, I thought wouldn't it be good to have a puzzle book whereby every page you solve gives you a numerical answer which would take you to another page in the book, and so on... 
Something disconnected from phones and the internet that you could stick in a bag and take with you on a long journey or lay in bed at night solving. Then after a few months, scribbled in a notebook stashed in my pocket, The Paper Labyrinth was born.

The basic premise of the book is that you solve a variety of riddles and puzzles, each giving you a direction to somewhere else in the book. Some are single puzzles, some have multiple parts but ultimately you should be able to solve the entire book - but The Paper Labyrinth ends unresolved. The player is left with a 5-digit-code and the promise that some day that code will unlock something new...


Fast forward to now, 2021. The Paper Labyrinth is the best selling book I have ever published and I think it is time to write a second (and final) installment. I've already started writing, sticking to the popular format of The Paper Labyrinth, but adding new twists including alternate paths through the book, a few tricks and traps, and some decisions for the reader to make which I hope will make the already addictive format even more engrossing! This is where your help comes in, pledging to help me create this book helps me dedicate time to work solely on this project and create something (hopefully) as good or even better than the original!

ADDED EXTRAS:
Due to your amazing and overwhelming support, I have added a few extras to the books which will come with all rewards;
BOOKMARKS MINI GAME - Everyone needs a bookmark (especially in The Paper Labyrinth) and these aren't just that - they're a mini puzzle game too! (And just like The Paper Labyrinth, in two parts!) The first will come with any add-ons of Book One and The Power of Four, and the second (or both bookmarks) will come in July with your copy of Book Two / The Complete Book! They line up with eachother allowing you to solve them once you're all done with your book.They are printed both sides with a lovely foil effect on the front!
DUST JACKETS AND INNER COVER PAPERS - (for all hardback 'The Complete Paper Labyrinth' pledges) these will help keep your book in the best condition possible and hopefully feel a little extra special!

campaign.story:
Tabletop Tycoon will donate a game to Toys for Tots for each copy of Newleaf, Mistwood, and The Complete Collection sold through this campaign. To date, as a company, we’ve raised enough to donate over 75,000 games to kids prior to the start of this campaign. In this campaign, your support has allowed us to raise enough to donate over 40,000 games to kids (and growing as we add more backers!)
Artist impression of prototype components. Final version subject to updates.
New critters and new ideas are arriving every day at the Newleaf train station! Being the first official city of Everdell, Newleaf has grown into a thriving destination with numerous exciting opportunities to discover and explore. Attract eager visitors to your city, make your reservations, travel further with tickets, and build the most prosperous city Everdell has ever seen! Prepare to experience an all-new Everdell that will keep delighting and surprising you for many more seasons to come.
Artist impression of prototype components. Final version subject to updates.
Lurking in the depths of Mistwood, the cunning and villainous Nightweave plots to take over Everdell with the aid of her spiderlings. Pit your wits against Nightweave and her sticky schemes in both solo and two-player games, and recruit heroes of yore from our More Legends and Corrin Evertail expansion packs as well as transform your farms with our new Through Every Season expansion pack!

Artist impression of prototype components. Final version subject to updates.
Dive tailfirst into the world of Everdell with the Complete Collection. Build a city of critters and constructions and explore the Emerald Valley and beyond; celebrate the Bellfaire, wonder at Newleaf’s mechanical marvels, trek into the Spirecrest Mountains, explore the underwater depths of Pearlbrook, and chance the dangers of Mistwood. Play against automated opponents including the dastardly Rugwort and cunning Nightweave, meet heroes of renown in our Legends II and Corrin Evertail expansion packs, and find abundance in new farms in our Through Every Season expansion pack. Everdell is easy to learn, yet offers satisfying strategic depth and endless replayability.

Will the sun shine brightest on your city?
Artist impression of prototype components. Final version subject to updates.

New to Everdell?
Check out this great How to Play video from Watch it Played!
Within the charming valley of Everdell, beneath the boughs of towering trees, among meandering streams and mossy hollows, a civilization of forest critters is thriving and expanding... Everdell is a game of dynamic tableau building and worker placement played over four seasons. Whoever makes the most impressive city wins! 

On your turn, you can take one of three actions:
a) Place a Meeple: You have a collection of wooden Critter meeples. You can place these on the board locations, events, and on Destination cards. Critter meeples allow you to perform various actions to develop your city: gathering resources, drawing cards, and taking other special actions.
b) Play a Card: Each player is building and populating a city; a tableau of up to 15 Construction and Critter cards. There are five types of cards: Travelers, Production, Destination, Governance, and Prosperity. Cards generate resources (twigs, resin, pebbles, and berries), grant abilities, and ultimately score points. The interactions of the cards reveal numerous strategies and a near infinite variety of working cities.
c) Prepare for the next Season: Critter meeples are returned to your supply and you gain bonuses depending on the season. The game is played from one year’s winter through to the end of autumn. Players add up the points from their cards and other bonuses and whoever has the highest total wins!
New content that will delight and surprise you for many more seasons to come!
Golden Occupied Tokens
The new Critter and Construction cards in Newleaf are played like normal Critter and Construction cards from the base game, except that you use Golden Occupied tokens instead of normal occupied tokens. These Golden Occupied tokens are limited -- a player can never use more than 3 in a game! These new cards are very powerful, so choose wisely which you'll spend your Golden Occupied tokens on! 

Through Every Season Cards
Since the beginning of Everdell’s history, farming has been a vital part of the valley’s way of life. Farmers face a number of challenges through the four distinct seasons of the year and must adapt as the weather changes. Experience the story of an Everdell farm throughout the year!
The 8 new special Farm cards in Mistwood replace the basic Farms in your Everdell game. These often give you the choice of two abilities, and you choose which of these abilities to use each time the card activates.

More Legends
Legendary cards represent unique Critters and Constructions that are powerful upgrades of other Critters and Constructions. Use them when you are familiar with the base game, and are looking forward to a twist on a regular game! The More Legends cards in Mistwood are added into a game of Everdell in the same manner as the Legends from Everdell: Collector's Edition.
New ideas are arriving every day!
Station Cards
Faceup Critter and Construction cards on the Station board work like Meadow cards and may be played on your turn, but whenever you play a card from the Station, also gain the reward listed on the Train Car tile beside the card! This reward is gained after you have fully resolved the played card and any additional cards that may have activated as a result. After you've gained the reward, replenish both the Train Car tile and the card played.
Remember: cards on the Station board are not Meadow cards, and therefore any abilities that affect Meadow cards (such as the Inn) do not apply to Station cards!

Visitors
Newleaf is a bustling and growing city in Everdell, and now that the railway system is in full operation, many new critters and big ideas are coming into the Emerald Valley. The Visitor cards that come into play on the Station Board offer players a new end game scoring opportunity!
To gain a Visitor card on your turn:
Place a worker on the Station. The Station is a shared location, allowing several workers at once, but you may only have 1 of your workers on this location at a time.
Choose 1 of the faceup Visitor cards and discard it facedown on the Visitor discard pile.
Reveal 1 new Visitor card and choose 1 of the 2 faceup Visitor cards to take and place by your city. If you do not want either of the faceup Visitors, you may draw 1 from the top of the Visitor deck instead. If you selected one of the faceup Visitors, replace its card with another one from the Visitor deck.
Gain the reward shown on 1 of the Train Car tiles by the Station; set that tile aside and draw a replacement tile.
Visitor cards will score their listed point values, if your city contains their requirements at the end of the game. Visitor cards that you have obtained and failed to please (by not meeting their requirements) are not worth any points at the end of the game.

The Knoll
You may place a worker on the Knoll to choose any 3 cards from the Meadow and/or the Station to discard. Replenish the discarded cards from the main deck, and draw any 3 cards into your hand from the Meadow and/or the Station. After drawing your cards, you may then gain the reward shown on 1 of the Train Car tiles. Set that Train Car tile aside and draw a replacement tile from the bag. Finally, replenish the 3 cards you drew into your hand.
The Knoll is a shared location, allowing several workers at once, but you may only have 1 of your workers on this location at a time.
Everdell has a brand new villainess!
Now while playing Everdell, you can pit your wits against Nightweave, our newest automated player for solitaire and two-player games. Nightweave is designed to function like a real player at your table: she has her own hand of cards, Prepares for Seasons on her own schedule, and, most importantly, she has her own agenda!

Nightweave has her own Big Critter meeple along with 8 spider meeples (not just 6!) that will move about the board to do her bidding -- blocking exclusive Locations, taking events away before you can get them, and even enacting Plots and Plans that will interfere with your options as a player, reminiscent of the Weather cards from Spirecrest.  She has eight different personalities that influence what she targets and focuses on, so there's lots of variety in gameplay!

What Happens on Nightweave's Turn?
Turn over the top card of Nightweave's Activity deck. These cards are the heart of her decision-making during the game, instructing her to play cards into her city, place spider meeples on previous, exclusive Locations, take a Basic or Special event, etc.
Nightweave will perform the first action listed for her current season, if possible. If she cannot perform this action for any reason, she will take the second action for her current season. If she cannot take that action either, she will perform as much of the Default action at the bottom of the card as she can. campaign.story:
Lone Shark Games, the publisher of the puzzle novel The Maze of Games and Puzzlecraft: How to Make Every Kind of Puzzle, brings you our newest foray into puzzle fiction: the crossword comic Letters to Margaret. Here's Hayley Gold, the cartoonist behind this groundbreaking new type of graphic novel.
Hey, Kickstarter crowd, this is Hayley Gold, crossword cartoonist, here to present you with my latest puzzle-based comic, Letters to Margaret. Here’s what it’s all about:
If you thought the world of crosswords was black and white, you’d be… mostly right. They, like all of us, are caught in a highly polarized imbroglio between sides stuck in their black and white thinking. Well, maybe it’s time to consider how the other side sees things. So, I made a similarly polarized comic. It’s so polarized that it’s literally divided in half. The same series of events are twice-told, each from a different character’s perspective, and each packing a different set of solvable crosswords by Mike Selinker and Andy Kravis. You can solve along and take the puzzles apart with the characters, maybe gaining new perspectives on things as you work your way through each side.
Prototype books seen from the front and back. Image not final.
One side’s protagonist, Derry Down, believes that the New York Times crossword reinforces stereotypes, is non-inclusive, and uses offensive clues. Across the aisle (and the bookbinding) is Margaret "Maggie" A. Cross, who's maddened by blogger critiques that call for stemming the choice of words and topics broached in the NYT crossword in the name of sensitivity. The twosome’s opinions clash on the web, in the crossword blogosphere, and IRL on the campus of Columbia University — but to complicate things, Maggie is visited by the voice of puzzles past: Margaret Farrar. The first editor of the Times crossword emerges in the form of letters, as Ms. Farrar attempts to edit Maggie’s amateur puzzle with a 1960s sensibility.
Letters to Margaret offers a closer look at the issues facing crosswords today from multiple perspectives and multiple time periods, and all sugar-coated with a healthy dose of romcom antics and puzzles for the reader to solve alongside the protagonists. So, in a crossword landscape — and a sociopolitical landscape — that’s so strictly divided, can two sides meet to create a whole? That’s a puzzle that is literally for you to solve.
Letters to Margaret is a 128-page graphic novel split in two parts, one facing the opposite direction from the other. You can read Maggie’s tale first or Derry’s tale first and your reading experience will be different each time. But that’s not all you can do. Letters to Margaret is the first comic book you can solve.
If you’re a fan of Lone Shark’s interactive novel The Maze of Games, you may have a clue where this is going. But “having a clue” is the whole point of the book. The book is loaded with crossword puzzles that you can solve before they appear in the characters’ hands. Several are puzzles of the kind you’d find in the New York Times — in fact, in the story, they are NYT crosswords ranging from Wednesday to Saturday in difficulty. Others are the crosswords that Maggie, an up-and-coming cruciverbalist (that’s a fancy term for a crossword constructor), submits to the New York Times — and then gets a few edits from its long-passed editor, Margaret Farrar.
The crosswords are constructed by my friends Andy Kravis, a puzzle editor at the New Yorker, and Mike Selinker, who wrote and constructed The Maze of Games among many other puzzle projects. You can read the book without solving the puzzles, letting the characters guide you through the crosswords. Or you can solve the puzzles first and experience the world of crosswords the way the characters do.
Thank you for asking! You can read the first chapter of Maggie's book on this page. Or you can just look at the sample pages and images below. Here you can see the adventures of Maggie, Derry, Amanda, Prof. Dodgson, and our two arrows, Ebony and Irony, who provide narration throughout.
Letters to Margaret is a 128-page premium graphic novel. You can get the printed book at the $24 level. Each physical book comes with a PDF so you can print off the crossword pages and solve them without writing in your book, if you so choose. For crossword aficionados, we’ll also provide the puzzles in the .puz format, which allows solving in apps such as AcrossLite. And there's a digital art and puzzles pack with all sorts of goodies in it (see Are There Stretch Goals?).
Prototype book. Image not final. Oreos not included.
You can get just the digital book at the $10 level. The digital files will come with a PDF and the .puz crossword files, as well as everything in the digital art and puzzles pack.
Code pencils. Image not final.
If you want some pencils to solve the book, we've got the pencils for you. At the $63 Solver's Bundle level you'll get the physical and digital books and our hand-crafted code pencils, with a host of solving tools printed on the sides. We haven't sold code pencils for six years, so we're thrilled to bring them back. Designer Eric Harshbarger has created six unique Letters to Margaret code pencils, each of which provides a set of tools for solving puzzles. On each pencil's six faces are six codes or sequences critical for puzzle solving (though you don't need them for the crosswords in this book). In each dozen, you get two each of the following:
Pencil #1: Alphabet, Braille, Morse code, binary, ternary, index numbers (1-26),
Pencil #2: Alphabet, moon type, nautical flags, semaphore, American Sign Language, pigpen
Pencil #3: Numbers, Roman numerals, telephone keypad letters, people on U.S. paper money, people on U.S. coins, keyboard shift characters
Pencil #4: Months, days in months, birthstones, Chinese zodiac, zodiac symbols, western zodiac
Pencil #5: Numbers, powers of two, square numbers, cubic numbers, prime numbers, Fibonacci sequence
Pencil #6: Powers of ten, SI prefixes, SI symbols, imperial ruler in inches, metric ruler in millimeters, magnitudes
Finally, you collectors can get a signed book with signatures from the creative team at $75 Signed Graphic Novel level. Or you can add to that a set of pencils at the $99 Signed Solver's Bundle level. Or you can get all that and a whole library of Lone Shark books at the $200 Every Lone Shark Book level.
There are no shipping costs listed, because you’ll add those on in Lone Shark’s pledge manager after the campaign ends. Shipping costs will be approximately $10 to $12 in the United States and Canada. We’re sad to say that puzzle books cannot be shipped Media Mail, because the U.S. Postal Service doesn’t like fun. The physical goods can only be sent to the U.S. and Canada, because the shipping cost elsewhere is insane. If you're interested outside North America, please fill out this interest-gauging page.
If you are a retailer or distributor, please contact us at our talk page.
Yes! To get any of these add-ons, click the button that says Manage your pledge, then click the button that says Change your pledge and select a pledge amount. Click the Add button next to items you want to add, then click the Continue button and then the button that says Confirm changes. That's a lot of clicking! Here's what you can get.
There's a printed version of an 8-page Letters to Margaret mini-comic by Hayley and crossword star Robyn Weintraub that you can get for $5! Simply select or manage your pledge for a physical book (or more) and select the add-on for Bonus Letters to Margaret Mini-Comic.
A scene from the bonus mini-comic. Image not final.
You can get Lone Shark's other books by adding them after selecting your pledge level. 
The Maze of Games is our interactive puzzle novel by Mike Selinker and Pete Venters. The pages are in the wrong order, and you have to solve the puzzles to make the narrative make sense. You can get the hardcover and its companion projects The Theseus Guide to the Final Maze, the Maze Map, and The Keymaster's Tome separately or in one Keymaster's Bundle.
Puzzlecraft: How to Make Any Kind of Puzzle is our puzzlemaking guidebook, written by Mike Selinker and Thomas Snyder with a foreword by Peter Sagal. You can get it with The Puzzlecraft Workbook, a handy primer by Gaby Weidling that puts your puzzlemaking skills to use on a project.
Dealer's Choice: The Complete Handbook of Saturday Night Poker details all the basics of poker and then dives into more than 400 poker variants, many born from the fevered imaginations of authors James Ernest, Phil Foglio, and Mike Selinker. Features many hilarious illustrations by Phil.
Game Theory in the Age of Chaos is Mike Selinker and Richard Malena-Webber's 532-page tome of essays about politics and game theory. If you want to make sense of the last half decade through the lens of Risk, Monopoly, and D&D, this book will help with that.
There's a $200 Every Lone Shark Book level that gets you a signed copy of Letters to Margaret and everything in this section, including the bonus mini-comic.
For any of those books, complete your pledge and select what you want from the Add-On menu. Other Lone Shark products will be made available in our PledgeManager after the campaign ends.
There are! We unlocked eleven stretch goals during this campaign!
We've added two 50-crossword digital volumes called Crosswords of Wisdom, a digital wallpaper set, "outtake" puzzles that didn't make it into Letters to Margaret, a digital book of tile crosswords, another crossword pack, a digital bonus Letters to Margaret story with a Robyn Weintraub crossword, a digital pack of rows garden puzzles, a cartoon crossword sampler from Patrick Merrell, two digital packs of marching bands, and a digital giant crosswords puzzlepack. You can read all about those stretch goals in this update, this update, this update, and this update.
C'mon, this is us we're talking about. Of course there are!
It's time for a little sugary sweet puzzle romance! For the length of the campaign, you’ll get messages from a secret admirer who will shower you in New York Times-style mini-crosswords. You can solve these crosswords in the updates to earn conversation heart badges! These convo hearts have a zoological touch that crossword fans will love. Because everyone knows that when puzzles and LOVE mix, you get a VOLE.
There are seven mini-crosswords, each leading to a candy heart badge that features an animal that shows up in crosswords a lot, such as EMU. Each crossword also contains an answer that’s an animal. Here are all the mini-crosswords:
The first puzzle for the Red heart is here!
The second puzzle for the Orange heart is here!
The third puzzle for the Yellow heart is here!
The fourth puzzle for the Green heart is here!
The fifth puzzle for the Blue heart is here!
The sixth puzzle for the Indigo heart is here!
The seventh puzzle for the Violet heart is here!
To get each badge, go to this submission site, pull down to the right candy heart color, and enter the animal you find in the blank. You can use the badges as your social media icon on Facebook, Twitter, or Kickstarter. In fact, we’d really like it if you did!
Here are the badges without their candy heart messages. 
Of course, you don’t know your secret admirer’s identity — it wouldn’t be much of a secret otherwise, naturally. To find out your admirer’s name, you’ll need to solve all seven mini-crosswords and follow the metapuzzle instructions to get your eighth badge, the Rainbow badge. Good luck solving this sweet puzzlehunt!

Letters to Margaret is already finished from a creative point of view. Its text, art, and graphic design are all done. So, shortly after the campaign ends, we’ll be able to send it through an editing pass and then send it to press. It’ll take several months to print and ship, and there are always challenges with that, especially during a pandemic. We’ve had several projects delayed by production and shipping problems that we might not have in other times. That said, we’ve printed and shipped tens of thousands of books and games we made in our previous ten Kickstarters.

- We present the rewards as close to their final form as we can, but the final look and content could differ from what is presented here.

updates.update_content:
Great news! Now that we're done with sensitivity edits and puzzle testing and layout, we've sent Letters to Margaret and the mini-comic You Can't Make Up This Stuf to the printer. It turns out that sending a double-sided, half-of-it-backward-and-upside-down comic to the printer is more complicated than you might think! But it's all done.
Now we're beginning a step where we get samples made in various paper and printing formats so that we can determine what's best for this particular comic. We'll then approve one of those for printing sometime not too long from now.

campaign.story:
The sky is darker, the tea is colder, and the worst is still to come…
This campaign includes these three gloomy goodies:
 Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall standalone card game
 Gloom Grief Case deluxe storage box
 The Gloom Chronicles campaign-style mini-expansion
Misery and mysteries abound at Hemlock Hall, the imposing estate of Lord Wellington-Smythe and his eccentric family of misfits. When you’re invited inside for an evening’s entertainment, what could possibly go wrong? Will you Cuddle with Cats or Thwart a Thief? Will you Brawl Over Brandy or Fall Prey to the Plague? At Hemlock Hall, awful amusements become deadly diversions with the flip of a card.
Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall is a darkly humorous stand-alone competitive storytelling card game for two to five players. To win, you make your characters suffer the greatest tragedies possible before passing on to the well-deserved respite of death.  The player with the most negative score wins. And in Gloomier, the winner gets the final word: Who was the murderer? How did the heist end? You decide!
Gloomier features transparent plastic cards, allowing a character’s score — and story — to evolve as cards are stacked on top of each other. You don’t need prior experience to play Gloomier, but Gloom fans will find that A Night at Hemlock Hall expands the storytelling aspect of Gloom with new, specially-designed story prompts. And this full stand-alone game includes 6 new Stories and 14 new Guests that can be used with any edition of Gloom. So dare to enter Hemlock Hall, and see what delightful disaster awaits!

Like all Gloom games, Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall is a storytelling game. Stack transparent cards to boost your score and make your characters’ tales the most tragic — while blighting opponents with good fortune. Then, tell the story of these miserable misanthropes.
When you play an Untimely Death card on a character, they die and their negative score is locked in, but the story continues until all of one player’s characters have perished. Then, all players tally their scores.The player whose characters had the most tragic lives (and the most negative score) is the winner.
Points are important, but the best part of Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall is building increasingly sad, and increasingly silly stories with your fellow players. If you like Nightmare Before Christmas, The Addams Family, or A Series of Unfortunate Events, we think you’ll enjoy the absurd dark humor of Gloomier.

Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall contains:
 110 transparent plastic cards (including 14 new Guests, 6 Story cards, a new cast of Characters, and a variety of new Modifier, Event, and Untimely Death cards to bolster your tragic tales)
A 12-page, color, totally redesigned rulebook 
An attractive tuckbox 
It’s a standalone expansion, which means you can play it by itself or combine it with any other Gloom games.

Gloom fans have been asking for it for years, and it’s finally here … a box big enough for all your Gloom games!
The luxurious Grief Case is large enough to hold every Gloom game produced thus far — that’s roughly 1500 Gloom cards — plus all your rules and extras, and your darkest secrets. (It’s even got room to accommodate another four full Gloom games or eight expansions, for when you add future Gloom games to your collection.)
This case is extremely sturdy! 4mm thick laminated chipboard will make this the strongest game box in your collection, sure to hold up to a lifetime of use. Or, of course, 'til Untimely Death.
 Soft Touch finish adds a luxurious velvety-soft texture for instant tactile appeal and resistance to fingerprint marks. It also makes sliding the lid off the box both quick and satisfying.
 Spot gloss and red metallic foil add texture and shine to highlight design elements.
This deluxe box comes with its own thick acrylic dividers, so you can sort and cross-reference your games and cards in whatever way makes the most sense to you.
And more! Follow our backer updates for behind-the-scenes looks while we finalize production.
design subject to change
And don’t worry, if you’re missing a few Gloom games, we’ve made them all available as add-ons for this campaign so you can easily complete your collection!


Lots of Kickstarter campaigns (including several of ours!) have lots of different stretch goals to unlock. For this Kickstarter, we’re focusing on just one big one: The Gloom Chronicles. Chronicles is an expansion for the Gloom series, turning Gloom into a serialized, campaign-style game. It is included with all pledge levels, and has been improved through stretch goals to be the best The Gloom Chronicles it can be!
In Gloom, you and your friends weave tales of woe. But where does the story begin? Each card in The Gloom Chronicles expansion starts a new chapter for an ongoing game of Gloom, ties those games together as a serialized campaign, and adds variant rules, bringing new challenges to the story. You can choose a card at random, or you can start from the beginning and explore the ongoing chronicle of your family through an extended campaign. Your story begins with the Unhappy Birthday … but will your next game of Gloom involve a Tragic Train Ride, or will you end up at the infamous World’s Unfair?
The Gloom Chronicles is an expansion that can enhance any game of Gloom. You can use it with just one Gloom game, or let it navigate you through all the expansions. Narrative prompts give players a unified foundation for their stories, while variant rules challenge new and experienced players alike. The Unhappy Birthday awaits! What ignominious ending will your Gloom Chronicle have?

All pledge levels receive a discount on the entire Gloom line of products to complete your collection.
 The stretch goals for this campaign improved and expanded The Gloom Chronicles to its best version! Thank you for your support!
SINGLE ADD-ONS: This campaign’s Add-Ons page in checkout will let you pick up the game or two you missed, hassle free. They’re in stock and will ship very soon after the close of the campaign, before the main campaign rewards.
COMBINED SHIPPING: If you’re ordering more add-ons, visit our web store for savings on combined shipping. Just use the backer-only code posted in Update #2 when you check out. Products ordered via our web store ship immediately!


As a game, Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall is complete. Its rules have been extensively tested, the art and layout are finished, it just needs final proofreading before going to press. Work on The Gloom Chronicles and the Gloom Grief Case is also well underway. 
Our updates to backers will feature this handy chart to keep you informed on our progress at every step along the way:
Shipping is paid on checkout. Kickstarter will calculate the shipping and tax for your destination country when you back the project. If your country isn’t listed in the dropdown menu in Kickstarter’s checkout, and you’re interested in backing A Night at Hemlock Hall, please reach out to us at crowdfund@atlas-games.com and we’ll see if we can help.
The "shipping" charge includes applicable taxes like VAT or GST in the Canada, the UK and the EU. In other countries you may be liable for taxes and fees charged at the border. Whenever possible we use “Delivery Duty Paid” (DDP) services, so international packages shouldn’t be delayed at customs or flagged for extra fees. Backing our project on Kickstarter is not a useful way to avoid paying your local government’s taxes.
We ship your rewards ourselves. Rewards will ship from the Atlas Games warehouse in Duluth, Minnesota, USA. Based on our experience, this is more reliable and ultimately less expensive than a collection of global partners. In part due to our direct control of this facility, our shipping operations have remained both open and safe during the global pandemic.
Retailers get their usual terms. Retail tier backers pay shipping later, if at all, using Atlas Games’ standard direct-to-retail sales terms for shipping. See “Unruly Retailers,” below.
We believe that healthy retailers are key to a healthy hobby. We have a reputation for taking care of our retailer partners, and our Kickstarter campaigns are no exception. This campaign is retail-friendly because:
 The discount is what you expect. Your pledge gives you dollar-for-dollar credit to buy whatever mix of Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall, The Gloom Chronicles, and the Gloom Grief Case that are right for your store, at our standard retailer discount (50%) and regular shipping terms.
 Exclusive access to the Gloom Grief Case. This deluxe game box will not be made available through distribution.
 One free copy of The Gloom Chronicles, fully improved and expanded by the stretch goals of this campaign. Purchase more at your regular discount.
 Retail-only stretch goal. If 100 retail stores back this campaign, each one will receive a free demo copy of Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall. (As a point of reference, 124 retailers backed our last Gloom campaign!)
 Personal attention for ordering. Our salesperson will contact you to take your order, no need to worry about ordering add-ons now in Kickstarter.
 Immediate sales. Retailer backers may sell products from this Kickstarter as soon as they receive their orders.
 Gloom is a fan favorite. It’s one of our all-time best selling games, with over 350,000 copies sold and translations in 9 languages. Gloom is a proven winner for your store!
Any retailer questions can be directed to travis@atlas-games.com.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
At Atlas Games we’ve delivered seven Kickstarter campaigns, with our eighth manufactured and pending fulfillment. We invite you to visit the campaign pages for Feng Shui 2, Unknown Armies 3, Cogs and Commissars, Over the Edge 3, The White Box, Magical Kitties Save the Day, and Dice Miner to get a sense of how we deliver on our promises. We’d call your attention especially to the backer updates for Magical Kitties Save the Day, to give you a sense of how we handle things when the unexpected arises. Beyond our previous Kickstarters, Atlas Games has been publishing tabletop games and making good on our promises for 30 years.

At the same time: Yes, indeed, many things seem very uncertain these days. There are definitely risks that COVID-19 will disrupt our supply chain or affect our staff members. We promise that as challenges arise we will be transparent, plan sensible solutions, and keep you informed. If you have questions or concerns about Gloomier: A Night at Hemlock Hall, please contact us at crowdfund (at) atlas-games.com. Thank you for your support!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
Gloom cards are plastic, and very durable, for a lifetime of play.

The Grief Case is made from 4mm thick, laminated chipboard, making it one of the most durable game boxes you'll find, sure to last a lifetime. It's also future-proofed, with plenty of room for the Gloom games we have yet to make.
Reusability and recyclability
The Grief Case is the last Gloom box you'll ever need, and the tuckboxes that the individual games came in are fully recyclable.
Sustainable materials
We don't use shrink-wrap anymore, now individual decks are either banded with a paper band or held together with its box. Game boxes are kept closed with a small sticker.

campaign.story:
BIENVENUE!
Welcome to the campaign dedicated to our new book! We hope you will like it :)
🇬🇧 🇫🇷 🌍 This project is available in French and English. You will choose the language of your rewards during the pledge manager phase [suivez ce lien pour toutes les infos en français !]
Encyclopedia Standard Edition included in the $40 reward tier
Encyclopedia in a Nutshell
Encyclopedia is a 360-page lore book for your 5th Edition campaign, including dozens of ready-to-use cities, locations, NPCs, plot hooks, and magic items for your next game session.
 As a game master, you have a lot to do. Planning, writing, sometimes drawing, and much more!  We've been GMs for over 20 years and we are here to help. With this book, we wanted to offer you as much material as possible to make your job as a GM easier. Prepare your next game session or upgrade your worldbuilding by picking from the Encyclopedia’s rich contents and cook up your own unforgettable stories!
Encyclopedia Red Dragon Deluxe Edition included in the $70 reward tier and up
Download a 40-page Preview of the Encyclopedia
To download the 40-page preview of the Encyclopedia, click the following link. If you like what you see, back us to allow us to create more :)
Work on the Encyclopedia started in France in 2016. It took our studio four years to put together the 360 pages and hundreds of artworks depicting the cities, places, magic items, and NPCs within. The book is now translated and in the very last steps of proofreading and formatting for PDF. We plan to deliver a final version of the Encyclopedia PDF at the end of the campaign.
Cities and Places of Adventure
Across this book, you will find 15 cities and many locations ready to serve as the settings of your next adventures. Each of these places has its own identity, featuring many adventure hooks and dozens of memorable figures, both friends and foes: a kobold mining village, a diabolist city, a necropolis-city, a hobgoblin pirate port, and more! The Free City, described over 40+ pages, is split into 15 districts, which you can use separately, as the locales of urban adventures, or as part of a teeming metropolis.
This toolbox is perfect for veteran game masters who want to level up their homebrew campaign, as well as for beginners seeking readily usable content to begin their first campaign. This book can also be used as a campaign setting to play in a universe steeped in Sword & Sorcery and portraying colorful civilizations.

Level-up Your Next Story
Encyclopedia offers colorful and diverse game material spanning 4 civilizations, each highly distinct from the others. Every one has its own atmosphere, its own mysteries, and its own antagonists.
A meditating orc of the Iruuls - Available as a playable species in CREATURES
One of our main objectives was to step away from the tropes of classic fantasy, where orcs and other 'greenskins' are brutish and inherently evil. Here, orcs have cultures of their own, including pacifistic ones like the Iruul orcs, and hobgoblins have a thriving culture of trading.

Coat of arms of the Garden City
You can draw inspiration from these civilizations or use them as-is in a campaign of your creation… or you can feature them in the setting of Eana, which gathers them all!
 Free City. Join the guilds and schemes of the Free City, a cosmopolitan metropolis filled with many mysteries!
 Drakenbergen. Discover legendary valleys with hidden ancient ruins, majestic fjords, dwarven mines, raging volcanoes, and the vampiric kingdom of Kentigern, all nestled in the sprawling mountains of the Drakenbergen!
 Septentrion. Sail for faraway Boreïa, the gateway to the Septentrion, and explore these frozen northern lands, populated with fearsome frost giants and holding a portal to the frozen plane of Gemoniae!
 Kaan. Ride across the steppes of Kaan, venturing into baroque, contrasted, thriving, decadent city-states. Barter with the pirates of Tili’s Gulf or the shrewd merchants of Lihyân as you bear witness to past, present, and future empires!
A traveling hobgoblin merchant - Available as a playable species in CREATURES
Encyclopedia is your new cookbook for your next game sessions ^^
Magic Items
Encyclopedia includes more than fifty magic items. Each is tied to one of the locations or personalities described in the book, providing adventure hooks and springboards for new adventures.
You will also find 5 optional rules to customize the use of magic items in your campaign:
 Enchanted gems. Set magic gems in weapons and armor to grant them special, unique properties!
 Magic weapon sheaths. Keep the destructive power of your weapons under control with suitable sheaths.
 War paints. In preparation for battle, draw from the ancestral might of these magic Kaani war paints.
 Magic pearls. Discover the pearls of the stone giants, which enable them to go unnoticed!
 Progressive mirafaction. Under the influence of fate and the extreme energies they are subjected to, the personal belongings of adventurers can gradually become magic items. What used to be a fine sword, a family legacy, progressively turns into a more fearsome weapon, imbued with enchantments that will become manifest at key moments of the adventurer’s tribulations!
Modular System
Encyclopedia makes use of a modular system that lets each game leader define the atmosphere they wish to create for their stories. Each of the symbols listed below indicates related optional rules, adventures hooks, and setting elements that the leader can choose to make use of within a given campaign. Do you want your game to fit the canons of heroic fantasy? Use the rules labeled “Action” to make the adventurers all the more powerful and successful. Do you want to play a dark-fantasy, survival-oriented game? “Dark” and “Gritty” options have been designed for you and will give adventurers a hard time. 
Modular System Icons
Here are three examples: 
 Action. This icon indicates all the rules, magic items, and situations that offer epic options and emphasize the characters’ feats and achievements.
 Corruption. The Corruption icon shows situations and magic items that lead to corruption, or which are only relevant to a corrupted creature.
 Dark. The optional rules, magic items, and situations indicated by this icon are all related to horror, madness, or corruption.
Spice up your next campaign!
Stretch Goals!
The base goal will support the book’s printing. Beyond that, we have several bonuses and upgrades planned to thank you for your support. To ensure a reasonable delivery schedule, all the bonuses of this campaign have already been designed. Your support will enable us to manufacture them and, most of all, send them to backers at no extra charge! Most of the bonuses unlocked during this campaign will be available later (late pledge) but will then become paid options. 
With your support, we can keep the Fateforge series growing. Should this campaign’s backing go beyond the stretch goals planned, we will add digital bonuses exclusively, to make sure that the delivery won’t be delayed.
Here are the stretch goals :

150k Squirrel Familiar Mini 1 Inch plastic + STL

Above the $400K mark, we have organized polls with the backers for the new bonuses. All stretch goals are now unlocked... BRAVO !
Encyclopedia Rewards Summary

If you back this project before Friday, March 12th at 11 PM CET, you will get a cute 1.2-inch (30mm) plastic mini of the Pickpocat, along with an STL file of the miniature (digital backers will only get the STL file). You will also receive a 2-page PDF with the Pickpocat’s complete stat block for in-game use ^^ The Pickpocat may be offered as an addon after the campaign during the pledge manager, but nothing is sure for now. 
About the books and covers
There are three available covers for the Encyclopedia. The $70 reward tier and up allows you to choose between any of the 3 covers. You will choose your cover during the pledge manager phase.
Standard Edition (1) (scheduled to be available in retail)

Other than the cover, the content of each edition is exactly the same. Copies of the Red Dragon edition may be available at conventions or during special events, but not in retail. The Fateforge edition is intended for fans and collectors of the Fateforge series.

Fateforge is a self-contained RPG using the 5E augmented system. If you are already a 5E player, these books offer a new campaign setting, as well as a multitude of options and additional rules. If you are new to roleplaying games or do not own books using the rules of the 5th Edition of the oldest roleplaying game, these books contain all the SRD basics rules and all you need to get started!

campaign.story:
Find all the Hunted games and more at BestWith1.com!

Hunted: Wode Ridge is the third game in the Hunted series. In this installment, you (or you and a friend working cooperatively) will take on the role of a group of kids and their newfound alien friend and explore Wode Ridge looking for evidence of the town’s supernatural happenings. 
But be wary, the Darkness knows you’re on to it, so it’ll try to get you before you get it. 
Find enough evidence to figure out which monster is currently stalking the town and then defeat it before time runs out and the Darkness overtakes you...
(You can get the previous games in the Hunted series at the Best With 1 Games website.)
 *Playmat included at certain reward tiers and will fit inside the box!
 **Components are subject to change


While the core card play mechanism is the same for all Hunted games, Wode Ridge provides a totally different experience from the other games in the series and offers: 
 *Wode Ridge has over 3X the content of previous Hunted games.


*Placeholder artwork. The final art is going to look excellent.




"I think Gabe has done a fantastic job with Wode Ridge. He's moved the solid mechanics of the Hunted series in a new direction, captured the theme and narrative in an immensely fun way, and kept the gameplay quick and full of choices for both solo and cooperative play." -Mike, the One Stop Co-Op Shop
"Hunted: Wode Ridge is a wonderfully thematic and evocative game experience. Its beautiful, anime-inspired artwork and innovative deck-flipping mechanism immerses players in a fantastic world of intrepid kids on bikes dodging dangers ranging from the supernatural, the FBI, and even their parents! All while on a suspenseful quest for evidence to track down the evil mastermind, that plays in a compact yet action-packed 20 minutes. Loads of nostalgic fun!" -Martin Gonzalvez






*Backing at any level (even just $1) will get you access to the pledge manager. 

If you're a publisher and have licensing/localization inquiries please contact Michael Raftopoulos at michael@mobvanguard.com.
Join the Hunted Facebook community to get the latest on art, playtesting opportunities, and new games in the series!



Gabe Barrett - game design
Gabe is the creator of the Hunted series and the founder of the Board Game Design Lab. He's been designing games for over 10 years and loves getting people to the table.
Drew Corkill - graphic design
Drew is a professional UI/UX designer who is passionate about board games. He translates his knowledge of user experience design, interface design, and print production to create intuitive and well-designed gaming experiences.
Jorge Velez - art
Jorge is currently a freelance artist and former Illustrator at Floyd County Productions. He draws much inspiration from 90s era Japanese video games and illustrated movie posters.
Sara Perry - logistics
Sara is a game designer and board game freelancer specializing in logistics/shipping and customer support. When she's not wearing her many different game-related hats, you can find her baking, hiking, or playing with her puppy Gus.
Adventure Book Writers: Jimmy Andreakos, Joe Klipfel, Jono Naito, Meghan Malone, Patrick Goepfert, Sarah Shipp, Tyler Omichinski, & Zach Lorton

campaign.story:
What Once Went Wrong is a tabletop roleplaying game of altruism and discovery inspired by the TV show Quantum Leap. 
In the game, you portray a time traveler who "leaps into" the body of someone in the past in order to help fix something that went wrong in their life. Only when you have helped fix the problem can you leap out...and hopefully leap home. 
In addition to describing the world of the game, presenting challenges to the player, and portraying various other characters, the game master also portrays the observer, a guide from the traveler's time who helps the traveler by filling in missing information and suggesting things that might need fixing. 
The game is structured such that the GM does not know exactly WHAT change needs to be made for the traveler to leap out. They'll discover this together as the game is played. 
The game can be played "duet style" with just one GM and one player. There are also rules for having multiple players/time travelers.
A time traveler jumps into a skydiver while plummeting to the ground
What Once Went Wrong is a very rules-light RPG. At the end of important scenes, where the time traveler is potentially changing something about the subject's life, dice are rolled to determine how effective the attempt is.  An in-game currency called Destiny Points can be spent to help the traveler accomplish some things. 
During play, the GM secretly tracks a countdown that gets the traveler closer and closer to making the right change. A combination of this countdown and the results of the traveler's dice checks reveals what needed to be changed in the moment, allowing the GM and player discover this together. 
Story Structure and GM Tools
GMs will be provided with tools and guidance regarding how to build and craft a story of this type. The game requires only minimal preparation to get started, but the GM will improvise a fair bit during play, building off of what the time traveler does and creating new problems for them to fix. 
(The game will address the concept of personal agency and control of one's body. Such things might even become a central theme to game sessions you run, but that's up to you.)
A time traveler arrives just in time to help a little boy
The game will be approximately 24 pages long with grayscale art/photography with some color. PDFs will be fulfilled through DriveThruRPG.com, as will softcover books.
Shipping of softcover books is only available in the 48 contiguous US states. See "Shipping" below for reasons why.
Physical copies of the game can be shipped to the US fairly inexpensively.
However, shipping such a small book to anyplace else is ridiculously expensive. If you live outside the US and want a physical book, you have full permission to print and bind the PDF pages at a local office store/print shop. It'll cost you a fair bit less than what we'd have to charge to cover the printing and shipping costs of such a small book.
A time traveler jumps into an athlete just before the big hit
 Game Design and Layout: Craig Campbell (he/him) is an architect, podcaster, indie RPG designer, and the owner of NerdBurger Games. He is the designer of the award-winning CAPERS RPG, as well as several others. He has freelanced for a variety of other RPGs, enjoys exploring worlds not often explored in RPGs, and is a firm believer in the idea that there is no such thing as "too many games."
 Editing: Ginny Loveday (she/her) is a best-selling D&D designer and editor in addition to being the host of the Designer's Den TTRPG interview show on Twitch, and co-host of the DnD Roundtable podcast with Paige Leitman. Find out more at http://ginnyloveday.com. 
  Visual Artistry: Roger Creus Dorico (he/him) is a digital artist from Barcelona, exploring dark and fantasy themes through illustration, 3d, and animation.
Your pledge will go toward reimbursing the money spent up front to produce the game and to cover printing and shipping (for those US backers who choose that option).
